session.name: Liberty Index 2023 - U.S. Senate
session.description: Created by the Republican Liberty Caucus, the 2023 Liberty Index is a liberty-focused legislative scorecard for the U.S. Senate. The Liberty Index scores Republican Senators on 20 pivotal bills/votes from 2023 that either advance liberty or diminish liberty.

bills.title: This bill would have repealed the authorizations for use of military force against Iraq
bills.description: This bill would have repealed the authorizations for use of military force against Iraq.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed Senate 66-30, but failed to advance in the House

bills.title: This joint resolution terminated the national emergency concerning COVID-19 declared by the President on March 13, 2020
bills.description: This joint resolution terminated the national emergency concerning COVID-19 declared by the President on March 13, 2020.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 229-197 on 2/1/23, Passed Senate 68-23 on 3/29/23, Signed by President

bills.title: This joint resolution would have repealed President Biden's rule that currently allows the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide taxpayer funded abortions
bills.description: This joint resolution would have repealed President Biden's rule that currently allows the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide taxpayer funded abortions.

bills.title: The Fire Grants and Safety Act appropriates an additional $95 million annually through 2030 for the U
bills.description: The Fire Grants and Safety Act appropriates an additional $95 million annually through 2030 for the U.S. Fire Administration. Per the 10th Amendment, this issue should be left to states. With a $34 trillion national debt, spending increases like this are irresponsible.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed Senate 95-2, but failed to advance in the House

bills.title: This joint resolution would repeal the unconstitutional rule issued by the ATF that currently bans pistol braces
bills.description: This joint resolution would repeal the unconstitutional rule issued by the ATF that currently bans pistol braces.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 219-210 on 6/13/23, Failed Senate 49-50 on 6/22/23

bills.title: The Cruz amendment #421 to S
bills.description: The Cruz amendment #421 to S.2226 would prohibit the Secretary of Defense from issuing a COVID-19 vaccine mandate without congressional approval. It would also S.2226 Cruz

bills.title: The Cruz amendment #421 to S
bills.description: The Cruz amendment #421 to S.2226 would prohibit the Secretary of Defense from issuing a COVID-19 vaccine mandate without congressional approval. It would also reinstate any servicemembers fired over the COVID-19 vaccine mandate and restore the ranks of service members demoted due to the vaccine mandate.

bills.title: The Senate's first version of the 2023 NDAA
bills.description: The Senate's first version of the 2023 NDAA. This bill appropriated $886 billion for military spending, a $23 billion increase from the prior year. Adjusted for inflation, this is the largest military budget since World War II. With a $34 trillion national debt, this much spending is irresponsible. The bill also would have permanently reauthorized the Undetectable Firearms Act, an unconstitutional statute which bans firearms that can go through metal detectors undetected.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed Senate 86-11 on 7/27/23, but failed to advance in the House

bills.title: This continuing resolution would have funded the federal government from 9/30/23 through 11/17/23, at current funding levels
bills.description: This continuing resolution would have funded the federal government from 9/30/23 through 11/17/23, at current funding levels. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts, kicking the can down the road for another month and a half.
bills.vote_result_summary: Cloture Motion Passed Senate 77-19 on 9/26/23. The bill passed the Senate, but failed to advance in the House

bills.title: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding
bills.description: This continuing resolution approved 45 days of federal funding. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts, kicking the can down the road for another 45 days.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 335-91 on 9/30/23, Passed Senate 88-9 on 9/30/23, Signed by President

bills.title: Approximately 1,000 U
bills.description: Approximately 1,000 U.S. servicemembers are currently deployed in Niger without congressional approval. This joint resolution would force President Biden to remove those troops from hostilities in Niger.

bills.title: After Senate leadership amended the House version, the Consolidated Appropriations Act approves federal funding for numerous departments and agencies, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, the
bills.description: After Senate leadership amended the House version, the Consolidated Appropriations Act approves federal funding for numerous departments and agencies, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Agriculture, the Food and Drug Administration, the Department of Transportation, and the Department of Housing

bills.title: After Senate leadership amended the House version, the Consolidated Appropriations Act approves federal funding for numerous departments and agencies, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, the
bills.description: After Senate leadership amended the House version, the Consolidated Appropriations Act approves federal funding for numerous departments and agencies, including the Department of Veterans Affairs, the Department of Agriculture, the Food and Drug Administration, the Department of Transportation, and the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Many of these departments are unconstitutional, per the 10th Amendment. With a $34 trillion national debt, it is irresponsible to continue funding these departments without any signficant budget cuts.

bills.title: This continuing resolution approved another two and a half months of federal funding
bills.description: This continuing resolution approved another two and a half months of federal funding. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts,

bills.title: This continuing resolution approved another two and a half months of federal funding
bills.description: This continuing resolution approved another two and a half months of federal funding. It bypassed the formal budgeting process without any significant spending cuts, kicking the can down the road for another two and a half months.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed House 336-95 on 11/14/23, Passed Senate 87-11 on 11/15/23, Signed by President

bills.title: The Cloture Motion to H
bills.description: The Cloture Motion to H.R.815 would have allowed the Senate to bring this bill to the floor for consideration. Senate leadership planned to use H.R.815 as a vehicle to pass $110.5 billion in new spending, including $66 billion of foreign aid for Ukraine and $14 billion of foreign aid for Israel. With a $34 trillion national debt, these spending increases are irresponsible.

bills.title: The final version of the 2023 NDAA
bills.description: The final version of the 2023 NDAA. This 3,000 page bill appropriated $886 billion for military spending, a $23 billion increase from the prior year. Adjusted for inflation, this is the largest military budget since World War II. With a $34 trillion national debt, this much spending is irresponsible.The bill also extended the unconstitutional FISA program to 2025, which was inserted in conference committee, violating congressional rules. The bill also funds abortion services for military service members.
bills.vote_result_summary: Passed Senate 87-13 on 12/13/23, Passed House 310-118 on 12/14/23, Signed by President

bills.title: The Cloture Motion allowed the Senate to bring H
bills.description: The Cloture Motion allowed the Senate to bring H.R.2670 to the floor for consideration. It has a 60 vote threshold, which means Republicans could have stopped the bill if they remained unified in opposition to cloture.

bills.title: H
bills.description: H.R.2670 was amended in conference committee to include an extension of the FISA program. This language inserted into the NDAA violated Senate rules because it was not germane to the bill. To get around this, the Senate passed this motion to waive the rules, allowing adoption of the conference committee amendment. In short, to Waive Rules Senators could have blocked the FISA extension had they defeated this motion.
